awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Quantum Transport and Optoelectronics with Helical Crystals
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical abstract:
The physical properties of materials, and consequently how those materials may be put to work for the benefit of society, is dictated by which elements compose the material and how each element is arranged within the structure of the material.  When the elements selenium or tellurium bond together to form a crystal, the arrangement of the elements is rather unique: the atoms form tiny spiraling chains running in the same direction with many parallel chains weakly bonded together to create the crystal.  Given this unusual structure, it is not surprising that many new physical properties could arise.  The research team synthesizes these materials and incorporates them into electronic devices that create, control and probe the unusual properties.  For example, as electrons travel along the spiraling chains, they are expected to generate a large magnetic field that could be useful for information storage and processing.  As another example, stretching the spirals is expected to transform these materials from a semiconductor into a special type of metal in which new and useful quantum mechanical properties emerge.  This activity is integrated into a broad scope of educational and community-building efforts aimed at training students to enter the quantum science and technology workforce, communicating physics to the general public, and inspiring young students, particularly those from underrepresented groups, to choose careers in science and engineering.

Technical abstract:
Topological band theory has revolutionized the understanding of what kinds of quantum states are possible in condensed matter settings, and this understanding has led to the experimental realization of many of these states, including various types of topological insulators and Dirac, Weyl, and Majorana fermions. While these quantum states have been investigated with increasing vigor over many years, the development of devices based on quantum materials remains in its infancy, particularly for Weyl and Majorana systems. Such devices could control, optimize, utilize, and further probe some of these states, as well as create new ones. This project converges materials synthesis, two-dimensional material heterostructures, and quantum device fabrication/measurement to revisit two materials, elemental selenium and tellurium, and probe them in a new light as quantum materials. The objective is to experimentally answer fundamental questions about the properties and capabilities of these materials spanning a broad range of topics: the kinetic magneto-electric effect; Fermi energy tuning, strain modification, and confinement of gapped Weyl materials; and heterostructures of tellurium and layered superconductors as a potential Majorana platform.  Answers to these questions have the potential to establish trigonal Se and Te as premier quantum materials impacting a wide range of fundamental and applied topics including spintronics, valleytronics, topological (semi)metals, solar energy harvesting, and (topological) quantum information processing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project resulted in five key scientific findings:


1. Giant Topological Hall Effect in Centrosymmetric Mn2-xZnxSb
This study discovered a unique material, Mn2-xZnxSb, which exhibits a giant topological Hall effect. Researchers achieved this by substituting zinc into a manganese-based structure. This substitution tuned the magnetic properties, enabling the material to support stable, exotic spin structures called skyrmions. These findings are crucial for spintronic technologies, as they offer insights into creating devices that use electron spins for data storage and processing, potentially operating near room temperature.

2. Tuning Supercurrent in Josephson Field-Effect Transistors Using h-BN Dielectric
This research developed innovative Josephson transistors capable of controlling supercurrent flow using hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) as a dielectric layer. By incorporating this ultra-thin, high-quality insulator, the team preserved the superconducting properties of the device while enabling precise electrical control. This work enhances our ability to engineer quantum technologies, such as superconducting qubits for quantum computing.

3. Growth and Strain Engineering of Trigonal Te for Topological Quantum Phases
Scientists explored the growth of nanowires made of trigonal tellurium (Te), a material with unique chiral properties that can support topological quantum states. By introducing strain during growth, they demonstrated a pathway to manipulate the electronic properties of Te. This research opens new possibilities for creating devices that utilize quantum phases, such as future generations of quantum computers and sensors.

4. Visualizing Oxidation Effects on Magnetic Domains in Fe3GeTe2
The study investigated how oxidation influences the magnetic behavior of nanoscale Fe3GeTe2, a promising material for spintronic devices. The researchers found that partial oxidation enhances the creation of skyrmions, small magnetic structures ideal for data storage, while complete oxidation destroys these magnetic features. These insights provide a foundation for using controlled oxidation to design advanced spintronic technologies.

5. Near-Field Radiation Heat Transfer in Graphene and Black Phosphorene
This work examined how nanoscale heat transfer can be enhanced between two 2D materials: graphene and black phosphorene. By modulating their electronic properties through gate voltage and doping, the team demonstrated a dramatic increase in heat transfer efficiency. These findings contribute to the development of next-generation thermal management systems and energy-efficient nanoscale devices.

Education:  this project contributed to the education of several undergraduate and graduate students, including the production of two PhDs and one Master's degree. The PhDs are contributing to the national quantum research effort, and the Master's graduate is working as one of the only semiconductor process engineers in northwest Arkansas.  This project also led to outreach events for more than 100 members of the general public and added a two-week module on quantum computing to the undergraduate curriculum at the University of Arkansas.
